1. The Basics.name: Introduction
1. The Basics.description: MathStudio is a computational software for iPhone, iPad, Apple Watch, Mac and your web browser.

1. The Basics.name: Trigonometric Functions
1. The Basics.description:
Basic or Circular
sin(z), cos(z), tan(z)

Inverse
asin(z), acos(z), atan(z), atan(x, y)

Auxiliary
csc(z), sec(z), cot(z)

Auxiliary Inverse
acsc(z), asec(z), acot(z)

Hyperbolic
sinh(z), cosh(z), tanh(z)

Inverse Hyperbolic
asinh(z), acosh(z), atanh(z)

Auxiliary Hyperbolic
csch(z), sech(z), coth(z)

Auxiliary Inverse Hyperbolic
acsch(z), asech(z), acoth(z)

1. The Basics.name: Special Values
1. The Basics.description: Specials values such as π are represented using the @ symbol.

1. The Basics.name: Lists
1. The Basics.description:
Lists are an ordered collection of expressions separated by commas and surrounded by a pair of square brackets.

Elements of a list can be accessed by assigning the list to a variable. Lists are 1-indexed meaning the first element starts at index 1.

Lists elements in a variable can be accessed using an integer, range or a list of integers.

examples.title: Accessing elements in a list using a range
Accessing elements in a list using another list
Accessing elements from the end using the index and size operators
Combining lists using the transformation operator
Deleting elements in a list using the index operator

1. The Basics.name: Matrices
1. The Basics.description:
Matrices are an ordered collection of equal length lists separated by commas and surrounded by a pair of square brackets.

Elements of a matrix can be accessed by assigning the matrix to a variable or using the transformation operator. Matrices like lists are 1-indexed in MathStudio meaning the first element starts at index 1.

Matrix rows and elements can be accessed using an integer, range, list of integers or a matrix of integers.

examples.title: Set a column to a value
Set a submatrix to a value
Set a submatrix to another submatrix
Accessing a column in a matrix
Combining matrices using the transformation operator
Iterate over a matrix
rows:
m = @[10, 10]
for [row, column] in m
m(row, column) = row * column
end
m

examples.title: Drawing a matrix
rows:
data = @[29, 29]
for [row, column] in data
data(row,column) = gcd(row,column) > 1
end
ImagePlot(data, width=200, height=200)

1. The Basics.name: Calculus
1. The Basics.description:
The derivative of an expression is found using the derivative function or the derivative operator.

The integral of an expression can be found using the integrate function.

1. The Basics.name: Fourier Analysis
1. The Basics.description: Fourier analysis is the study of the way general functions may be represented or approximated by sums of simpler trigonometric functions.

1. The Basics.name: Units
1. The Basics.description:
Named units are created using the @ symbol. Unit conversions are done using the transformation operator (->).

Time
Seconds (s), Minutes, Hours (h), Days, Weeks, Months, Years, Decades, Centuries, Millennia

Volume
Gallons, Quarts (qt), Pints, Cups, Ounces, Tablespoons (tbsp), Teaspoons (tsp), Liters (L)

Length
Meters (m), Mile, Yard, Foot (ft), Inch

Weight
Grams (g), Pounds (lb), Ounces

Temperature
Celsius (C), Fahrenheit (F), Kelvin (K)

Computer
Byte, Bit

Angle
Degrees, Radians, Gradians, Turns, Mils

Currency
United States Dollar (USD), Canadian Dollar (CAD), Australian Dollar (AUD), New Zealand Dollar (NZD), Hong Kong Dollar (HKD), Euro (EUR), Yen (JPY), Pound (GBP), Swiss Franc (CHF), Swedish Krona (SEK), South Korean Won (KRW), Yuan (CNY), Singapore Dollar (SGD), Norwegian Krone (NOK), Mexican Peso (MXN), Ruppe (INR), Ruppe (RUB), Bitcoin (BTC), Brazilian Real (BRL), Danish Krone (DKK), Forint (HUF), Koruna (CZK), Kuna (HRK), Lev (BGN), Rupiah (IDR), Sheqel (ILS), Ringgit (MYR), Philippine Peso (PHP), Zloty (PLN), Leu (RON), Baht (THB), Turkish Lira (TRY), Rand (ZAR)

1. The Basics.name: Base Conversions
1. The Basics.description: Number can be represented in different bases using # symbol followed by b for binary, o for octal or x for hexadecimal.

1. The Basics.name: Regression Analysis
1. The Basics.description: Regression analysis is performed using the following functions in MathStudio.

1. The Basics.name: Natural Language
1. The Basics.description:
Natural language expressions are entered using the @ symbol and surrounded with parenthesis.

Try Ask MathStudio for more examples using natural language with MathStudio!
http://mathstud.io/ask

examples.title: Graphing
rows:
plot(cos(x),color=red)
@(plot sin x blue)
@(plot tan x green)
@(plot the derivative of cos x squared blue)
@(plot a vector field with x and negative y red)

1. The Basics.name: Constants
1. The Basics.description: Constants are returned with units using natural language expressions.

1. The Basics.name: Dynamic Variables
1. The Basics.description: Dynamic Variables are variables that update all entries.

2. Operators.name: Basic Operators
2. Operators.description: An operator is a special symbol that checks, changes, or combine values.  For example, the addition operator (+) adds two expressions together.

2. Operators.name: Double Power Operator
2. Operators.description: The double power operator (^^) returns the real valued root.

2. Operators.name: Comparison Operators
2. Operators.description:
The following comparison operators return 1 or 0 to indicate whether or the statement is true or false respectively.

  • Equal to (a == b)
  • Not equal to (a != b)
  • Greater than (a > b)
  • Less than (a < b)
  • Greater than or equal to (a >= b)
  • Less than or equal to (a <= b)

2. Operators.name: Logical Operators
2. Operators.description:
The logical NOT operator (!) is a unary operator that returns 1 if the expression is equal to 0 otherwise it returns 0.

The logical AND operator (&&) or (&) returns 1 if both expression are not zero otherwise it returns 0.

The logical OR operator (||) or (|) returns 1 if either expression is not zero otherwise it returns 0.

2. Operators.name: Compound Assignment Operators
2. Operators.description: Compound assignment operators combine the assignment operator (=) with another operation such as the addition operator (+=).

2. Operators.name: Type Comparison Operators
2. Operators.description:
The type comparison operators (===) and (!==) compares the types of two expressions.

The (===) operator returns 1 if both expressions are of the same type.

The (!==) operator returns 1 if both expressions are not of the same type.

2. Operators.name: Size Operator
2. Operators.description: The size operator ($) is a unary operator that returns the size of the expression.

2. Operators.name: Range Operator
2. Operators.description:
The range operator (..) creates a range with a start value and an end value. The transformation operator (->) can be used to add a step value to a range.

The size operator ($) can be used at the beginning or end of the range. This will use the size of an expression when used with the transformation operator (->).

examples.title: Range with a step value using the transformation operator

2. Operators.name: Transformation Operator
2. Operators.description:
The transformation operator (->) is very powerful and has many uses. It transforms an expression on the left using an expression on the right.

This operator creates a step value when used with a range. A range of 1..10 goes from 1 to 10 with a default step value of 1. A range of 1..10 -> 2 creates the same range with a step value of 2.

examples.title: Deleting elements in a list using the index operator
Inserting elements into a list using the index operator

2. Operators.name: Index Operator
2. Operators.description: The index operator (#) is used to create an index at a number or range to insert or delete elements.

examples.title: Delete the last element with the size operator
Insert at the end with the size operator

2. Operators.name: Union Operator
2. Operators.description: The union operator (@|) creates a new expression from the distinct elements in both expressions.

2. Operators.name: Intersection Operator
2. Operators.description: The intersection operator (@&) creates a new expression that contains only the distinct elements found in both expressions.

2. Operators.name: Difference Operator
2. Operators.description: The difference operator (@^) creates a new expression that contains all the distinct elements that are not in both expressions.

2. Operators.name: Double Modulo Operator
2. Operators.description:
The double modulo operator is useful for accessing an index in a list or matrix.

Lists are 1-indexed so using the single modulo operator can result in a bounds error because 1 % 1 is zero where as 1 %% 1 is one.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
colors=[red,magenta,blue]
for i in 1..6
Plot(i*sin(x), color=colors(i %% $colors)
end

2. Operators.name: Matrix Operator
2. Operators.description: The matrix operator (unary *) converts a value to a matrix.

2. Operators.name: Matrix Size Operator
2. Operators.description: The matrix size operator ($$) is a unary operator that returns the dimensions of a matrix.  If the expression is not a matrix then zero is returned.

2. Operators.name: Angle Operator
2. Operators.description: The angle operator (@a) or (@angle) enters a number in polar form (r ∠ θ).

2. Operators.name: Choose Operator
2. Operators.description: The choose operator (@c) or (@choose) finds the binomial coefficient. This operator is equivalent to Binomial(n, r) function.

2. Operators.name: String Concatenation Operator
2. Operators.description: The string concatenation operator (<<) combines values into a single string.

2. Operators.name: Conditional Operator
2. Operators.description:
The conditional operator is a ternary operator that takes three values.

If the first value is not zero than the second value is returned. If the first value is zero than the last value is returned.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
if(a) // ?
return b
else // :
return c
end

// return the lowest value
a=1
b=2
a < b ? a : b

// return the highest value
a=1
b=2
a > b ? a : b

2. Operators.name: Append Operator
2. Operators.description:
The append operator (@=) appends an element to the end of the list.

If the variable has not been assigned to a value a list is assigned with one element.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
Clear(a)
for i in 1..10
a @= i
end
a

2. Operators.name: Element Operator
2. Operators.description: The element operator (@?) checks whether an expression contains an element.

examples.title: Multiple Plots
rows:
Plot(sin(x), color=blue)
ParametricPlot(cos(u), sin(u), color=red)
PolarPlot(sin(2@theta), color=green)
ParametricPlot(2cos(u), 2sin(u), color=magenta)

3. Graphing.name: Time Graphing
3. Graphing.description:
The time variable (T) creates animated plots.

The time variable can be changed by assigning T to a list in the form of T=[start, end, frames].

4. Variables.name: Creating Variables
4. Variables.description:
This in an introduction to creating variables in MathStudio's scripting language. Like other scripting languages, MathStudio uses variable names to store and refer to values.

However unlike other scripting languages, variables do not need to have a value assigned to be used. Variables can be used to create algebraic expressions or set to a value such as the number.

Variables must start with a lowercase, uppercase or underscore and can include numbers but not spaces. The @ symbol followed by an underscore (_) in a variable name is used to denote a subscript. Strings can be set to a value when preceded by the @ symbol.

4. Variables.name: Unicode Characters
4. Variables.description:
Unicode characters are represented using the @ symbol. A unicode value is prefixed using @U followed by a decimal value such as @U9786. The @ prefix also supports named HTML character entity references.

@quot @amp @apos @lt @gt @nbsp @iexcl @cent @curren @brvbar @sect @uml @copy @ordf @laquo @not @shy @reg @macr @deg @plusmn @acute @micro @para @middot @cedil @ordm @raquo @iquest @Agrave @Aacute @Acirc @Atilde @Auml @Aring @AElig @Ccedil @Egrave @Eacute @Ecirc @Euml @Igrave @Iacute @Icirc @Iuml @ETH @Ntilde @Ograve @Oacute @Ocirc @Otilde @Ouml @times @Oslash @Yacute @THORN @szlig @agrave @aacute @acirc @atilde @auml @aring @aelig @ccedil @egrave @eacute @ecirc @euml @igrave @iacute @icirc @iuml @eth @ntilde @ograve @oacute @ocirc @otilde @ouml @divide @oslash @yacute @thorn @yuml @OElig @oelig @Scaron @scaron @Yuml @fnof @circ @tilde @Alpha @Beta @Gamma @Delta @Epsilon @Zeta @Eta @Theta @Iota @Kappa @Lambda @Mu @Nu @Xi @Omicron @Pi @Rho @Sigma @Tau @Upsilon @Phi @Chi @Psi @Omega @alpha @beta @delta @epsilon @zeta @eta @theta @iota @kappa @lambda @mu @nu @xi @omicron @rho @sigmaf @sigma @upsilon @phi @chi @psi @omega @thetasym @upsih @piv @ensp @emsp @thinsp @zwnj @zwj @lrm @rlm @ndash @mdash @lsquo @rsquo @sbquo @ldquo @rdquo @bdquo @dagger @Dagger @bull @hellip @permil @prime @Prime @lsaquo @rsaquo @oline @frasl @image @weierp @real @trade @alefsym @larr @uarr @rarr @darr @harr @crarr @lArr @uArr @rArr @dArr @hArr @forall @part @exist @empty @nabla @isin @notin @ni @prod @sum @minus @lowast @radic @prop @infin @ang @and @or @cap @sim @cong @asymp @ne @equiv @le @ge @sub @sup @nsub @sube @supe @oplus @otimes @perp @sdot @vellip @lceil @rceil @lfloor @rfloor @lang @rang @loz @spades @clubs @hearts @diams

4. Variables.name: Variable Functions
4. Variables.description: Variables functions are defined using parenthesis with a list of arguments.

4. Variables.name: Strings
4. Variables.description:
A string is an ordered collection of characters such as "Hello World" or "MathStudio". Strings are created using double or single quotes.

Strings are concatenated using the string concatenation operator (<<) which converts all values to a string.

4. Variables.name: Wildcards
4. Variables.description: Wildcard variables (~) are used for comparing expressions.

5. Scripts.name: Creating Scripts
5. Scripts.description:
Scripts are created using the @ symbol followed by the name of the script. Script names follow the same convention as naming variables.

Variables created in a script are only accessible within the script.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
@sumOf(numbers)
sum = 0
for number in numbers
sum += number
end
sum

5. Scripts.name: Semicolons
5. Scripts.description: Semicolons are can be used to write multiple separate statements on a single line.

5. Scripts.name: Comments
5. Scripts.description:
Comments are used to annotate your scripts.

Single-line comments begin with two forward-slashes (//).

Multiline comments start with a forward-slash followed by an asterisk (/*) and end with an asterisk followed by a forward-slash (*/).

examples.title: Multiline comments
rows:
a=6
/* this is a
multiline comment */
a^2

examples.title: Nested multiline comments
rows:
a=16
/*
this is the start of the first multiline comment

/* this is the second,
nested multiline comment */

this is the end of the first multiline comment
*/
sqrt(a)

5. Scripts.name: Variable Controls
5. Scripts.description: MathStudio can create several types of controls that change the value of variables interactively.

5. Scripts.name: Conditional Statements
5. Scripts.description: Conditional statements execute a set of statements only if that condition does not equal zero.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
temperatureInFahrenheit = 90
if temperatureInFahrenheit <= 32
return "It's very cold. Consider wearing a scarf."
else if temperatureInFahrenheit >= 86
return "It's really warm. Don't forget to wear sunscreen."
else
return "It's not that cold. Wear a t-shirt."
end

examples.title: If-Return statements
rows:
x=2
if x==1 return "one"
if x==2 return "two"
if x==3 return "three"
return "unknown"

5. Scripts.name: For-In Loops
5. Scripts.description: Iterates over a list, matrix or range.

examples.title: Iterate over a list
rows:
numbers = 1:10
sum = 0
for number in numbers
sum += number
end
sum

examples.title: Iterate over a range
rows:
sum = 0
for i in 1..10
sum += i
end
sum

examples.title: Using the transformation operator to change the step value of a range
rows:
sum = 0
for i in 1..10 -> 2
sum += i
end
sum

examples.title: Iterate over a matrices using multiple loops
rows:
data = @[29, 29]
for row in 1..29
for column in 1..29
data(row,column) = gcd(row,column) > 1
end
end
ImagePlot(data)

examples.title: Iterate over a matrix with a single loop
rows:
data = @[29, 29]
for [row, column] in data
data(row,column) = gcd(row,column) > 1
end
ImagePlot(data)

examples.title: Iterate over a list of matrices using multiple loops
rows:
matrices = @[3,4,5]
for i in 1..3
for j in 1..4
for k in 1..5
matrices(i,j,k) = i + j + k
end
end
end
matrices

examples.title: Iterate over a list of matrices using a single loop
rows:
matrices = @[3,4,5]
for [i, j, k] in matrices
matrices(i,j,k) = i + j + k
end
matrices

5. Scripts.name: While Loops
5. Scripts.description: A while loop performs a set of statements until a condition equals zero. These kinds of loops are best used when the number of iterations is not known before the first iteration begins.

examples.title: Examples

5. Scripts.name: Timing
5. Scripts.description:
The reset and time commands let you time how long it takes to run your code.

The reset command resets the timer and the time command returns the time in milliseconds.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
reset

numbers = 1:1000
sum = 0
for number in numbers
sum += number
end
sum

time

5. Scripts.name: Objects
5. Scripts.description:
Objects are an ordered collected of assignment lists.

The dot operator (.) is a shorthand way to access named elements in an object.

5. Scripts.name: Working with JSON
5. Scripts.description: MathStudio can parse JSON data into an object by using the json function or using the http function to parse JSON data from a URL.

examples.title: Parse a JSON string using the JSON function
Parse a JSON string using the JSON function with a filter
Convert a temperature from the JSON data
Plot the stock price of Apple using the HTTP function
rows:
prices = stocks(query, results, quote, *, Close)
round(prices)
dates = date("m/d", stocks(query, results, quote, *, Date))

// Plot the stock price of AAPL
ListPlot(prices, labels=dates, width=700, height=220, flipAxis=1)

A.name: abs
A.description: Returns the complex modulus (or magnitude) of a complex number.

A.name: AlternatingSeries
A.description:
This function approximates the given real number in an alternating series.

The result is returned in a matrix with the top row = numerator and the bottom row = denominator of the different terms.

Note the alternating sign in the numerator!

A.name: Angle
A.description: Returns the angle between the two vectors A and B.

A.name: Animate
A.description:
This function creates an animated entry. The variable is initialized to the start value and at each frame is incremented by step and the entry is reevaluated creating animation.

When the variable is greater than the value end it is set back to start.

parameters.name: start
parameters.text: The initial value for the variable.

parameters.name: end
parameters.text: The ending value for the variable.

parameters.name: [step]
parameters.text: The variable is incremented by this value at each frame.

parameters.name: [fps]
parameters.text: The number of frames per second.

A.name: Apart
A.description:
Performs partial fraction decomposition on the polynomial function.

Apart performs the opposite operation of Together.

A.name: Append
A.description: Appends one expression to end of another expression.

A.name: Arg
A.description:
Returns the argument (or phase) of a complex number.

The value is dependent on the angle setting which can be radians or degrees. You can manually set the angle mode per entry by using the keyword radians or degrees.

B.name: Bernoulli
B.description:
Returns the nth Bernoulli number n.

If z is given, returns the nth Bernoulli polynomial of z.

B.name: BesselI
B.description: Returns the Modified Bessel function of the first kind.

B.name: BesselJ
B.description: Returns the Bessel function of the first kind.

B.name: BesselK
B.description: Returns the Modified Bessel function of the second kind.

B.name: BesselY
B.description: Returns the Bessel function of the second kind.

B.name: Beta
B.description: Calculates the Beta function of m, n both real or complex variables.

B.name: Binomial
B.description: Finds the binomial coefficient. This function is the symbolic equivalent to nCr(n,r).

B.name: BinomialCDF
B.description: Computes the cumulative Binomial distribution at x with number of trials n and probability of success p on each trial.

B.name: BinomialPDF
B.description: Computes the binomial distribution at x with number of trials n and probability of success p on each trial.

B.name: BodePlot
B.description:
BodePlot creates a Bode plot for the given function.

The x-axis is a logarithmic scale and represents the frequency in rad/sec.
  • x = -2 : => ω = 0.01 rad/sec
  • x = -1 : => ω = 0.1 rad/sec
  • x = 0 : => ω = 1 rad/sec
  • x = 1 : => ω = 10 rad/sec
  • x = 2 : => ω = 100 rad/sec
  • x = 3 : => ω = 1000 rad/sec
When the frequency is not given, then ωmin = 0.01 rad/sec and ωmax = 1000 rad/sec.

The y-axis is either the magnitude in dB (mode=0) or the phase in degrees (mode=1) or the phase in radians (mode=2).

parameters.name: mode
parameters.text:
mode = 0 : magnitude plot (= default mode)
mode = 1 : phase plot in degrees
mode = 2 : phase plot in radians

parameters.name: x
parameters.text: The x-values of the first list.

parameters.name: [y]
parameters.text: The y-values of the first list.

parameters.name: [x2]
parameters.text: The x-values of the second list.

parameters.name: [y2]
parameters.text: The y-values of the second list.

B.name: Button
B.description: Creates a button that increments between a list of values.

C.name: Call
C.description: Executes a call to the given function and passes the included parameters to the function.  The function is evaluated.

C.name: Caps
C.description:
Tests for uppercase and lowercase letters in strings.

The mode parameter can be set to upper or lower.

C.name: Catalan
C.description: Returns the n<sup>th</sup> Catalan number.

C.name: Ceil
C.description:
Returns the smallest integer of the given value.

If z is a complex number, then ceil works on both the real and the imaginary part.

C.name: cFrac
C.description:
Calculates the simple continued fraction representation of the given number n.

D.name: DSolve
D.description:
DSolve is a differential equation solver.

The derivative of the variable is notated using derivative notation. MathStudio uses the single quotation character to represent the derivative of a variable or function.

f'(x) - First derivative
f''(x) - Second derivative
f'''(x) - Third derivative

Derivative Examples
Solve: y' + y = sin(t)
DSolve(y'(t)+y(t)=sin(t), y(t), .....)

Solve: y'' + 2y' + y = x
DSolve(y''(x)+2y'(x)+y(x)=x, y(x), .....)

The definite integral of the variable is represented by I(f(t), t) and denotes the integral of the variable f(t) with lower bound 0 and upper bound t. These bounds cannot be changed.

Integral Examples
∫(y) + y = sin(t)
DSolve( I(y(t),t) + y(t) = sin(t), y(t), .....)

The upper case character I indicates the integral and is a mandatory condition.

Initial values
When no initial values are given, then simple write the word no. The result returned contains the Constant C@_1.

For first order differential equations the initial value can be given as y(t)=value. When you ommit y(t), then y(0) is assumed.

For higher order differential equations, the initial values should be given as a list and are always referred to zero : [y(0), y'(0), y''(0), ...]

Examples with different initial values
Solve: y' + y = sin(t) with y(0) = 5
DSolve(y'(t) + y(t) = sin(t) , y(t) , y(0) = 5)
or
DSolve(y(t)' + y(t) = sin(t) , y(t) , 5)

Solve: y' + y = sin(t) with y(2) = 5
DSolve(y(t)' + y(t) = sin(t) , y(t) , y(2)=5)

Solve: y'' + 2y' + y = x with y(0) = 1 and y'(0) = 2
DSolve(y''(x) + 2y'(x) + y(x) = x, y(x), [1,2])

Solve: y'' + 2y' + y = x with no initial values
DSolve(y''(x) + 2y'(x) + y(x) = x, y(x), no)

Different form for exact first order differential equations.
Exact first order differential equation can be given with d@_x , d@_t , d@_y, ect.

First Order Examples
Solve: dy = sin(t) * dt
DSolve(d@_y = sin(t) * d@_t, y(t), .....)

Of course, this can also be written as the following equation.
DSolve(y'(t) = sin(t) , y(t), ...)
Note: The variable to be solved should still be written as y(t).

Results
Normally, DSolve tries to return the result as y(t) = function(t).

In case y(t) cannot be represented in a simple form then the result is returned in implicit form.
function(y , t) = 0

In the latter case, the text Implicit result is added to call the users attention that the result is not of the form y(t)=function(t).

parameters.name: equation
parameters.text: The differential equation to be solved. If no equal sign is found in the equation then DSolve assumes that the equation is equal to zero.

parameters.name: dependent(independent)
parameters.text: The dependent variable as a function of the independent variable. This should be in the form of f(t), g(t), y(t), y(x), x(t) and so forth.

parameters.name: values
parameters.text: The given initial values. For no initial values input the variable no.

parameters.name: mode=1
parameters.text:
mode=1 forces a solution to be solved for the dependent variable or returns the answer as an implicit equation if the answer cannot be solved for the dependent variable.
mode=0 solves implicitly.

F.name: Finance
F.description:
This is a simple financial function to calculate loan or investments. In case of loan, Pmt is a positive value. In case of investments, Pmt is a negative value.

Fill in the known values in the indicated order and use any variable name for the unknown. In the examples below, the unknown is indicated with it's own name but you can use any variable name.

Based on the examples from Stan Brown, Oak Road Systems.

parameters.name: [mode=0]
parameters.text:
mode=0 indicates an ordinary annuity (payments end of the month). This is the default mode and should not be given.
mode=1 indicates an annuity due (payments beginning of the month)

examples.title: Assume you want to set apart $50 at the end of each month for your child starting the same month as the child was born. How much will be available if the child turns 19 years old.  Assume an interest rate of 5% compounded monthly.
You have a $18,000 car loan at 14.25% per year for a period of 36 months.  Every month you pay $620.  How big is the payoff amount after 24 months?
You are buying a $250,000 house, with 10% down, on a 30-year mortgage at a fixed rate of 7.8%. What is the monthly payment?
If you loan $3500 at 6% rate and and you pay back $100 per month.  How many months do you have to pay?
In the above example, you will make payments for 38 month.  How much will you pay for the last month?
If you deposit $100 per month over 5 years at 6% interest, how much money will you have at the end?
You have $15,000 in a 5% savings account, which is compounded monthly. How long can you withdraw $100 a month?
You want to purchase a 20-year annuity that will pay $500 a month. If the guaranteed interest rate is 4%, how much will the annuity cost?
On the same day every year, you put $2000 into stocks. If the market rises 8% a year, how many years will it take you to accumulate $40,000?
If you deposit $300 at the beginning of each month over 6 years at 10% interest, how much money will be in the fund at the end?

The monthly rent on an apartment is $950 payable at the beginning of the month.  If the current interest is 12% compounded monthly, what single payment 12 months in advance would be equal to a year's rent.
To obtain an amount of $3,000 ten years from now, earning 10% annually, what amount would have to be invested on a yearly basis in an annuity due form?
The time $1,500 is needed and you know in advance that you have 10 years to obtain it.  What annual interest rate would a $100 annuity due have to earn for you to achieve this goal?
You are doing a one time investment of $2,500.  What is accumulated value after 10 years at a fixed interest rate of 5%?
You need $19,500 within 5 years from now. How much do you need to deposit today at a fixed interest rate of 3.25%?
What interest rate would be needed to receive $20,000 after 20 years when you deposit $8,000 now?

f(t1) is the function definition for t1 < t < t2

Total period of the function is given by [ tn+1 - t1 ]

mode = 1 returns the complex form.

Use -1 for a left sided limit.

L.name: LinearFit
L.description: Fits the data to the form y=a*x+b.

L.name: LinearFitModel
L.description: Finds the model that fits the data to the form y=a*x+b.

L.name: LinearFitPlot
L.description: Fits and plots the data to the form y=a*x+b.

L.name: List
L.description:
Creates a list of the given length.

This function can also take the following input to create a list of expressions.
list(expression, variable=[start, step, length])

L.name: ListMap
L.description: Creates a new list by calling a script on each element or by using a mapped value on each element.

L.name: ListPlot
L.description:
ListPlot plots single or multiple lists of numeric data.

Lists can also be entered as a matrix of points.
[[x,y],[x2,y2],[x3,y3],...]

parameters.name: x
parameters.text: The x-values of the first list.

parameters.name: [y]
parameters.text: The y-values of the first list.

parameters.name: [x2]
parameters.text: The x-values of the second list.

parameters.name: [y2]
parameters.text: The y-values of the second list.

L.name: ListPlot3D
L.description: Plots 3D list data.

L.name: Ln
L.description: Returns the natural logarithm (base: e) of the given number z.

L.name: LnFit
L.description: Fits the data to the form a+b*ln(x).

L.name: LnFitModel
L.description: Finds the model that fits the data to the form a+b*ln(x).

L.name: LnFitPlot
L.description: Fits and plots the data to the form a+b*ln(x).

L.name: LnGamma
L.description: Returns the Log Gamma(z) function.

L.name: local
L.description: Defines a local variable.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
// b is still defined here
b

L.name: Log
L.description: Returns the common or Briggs logarithm (base: 10) of the given number z.

parameters.name: [n]
parameters.text: Base of logarithm.  The default value is 10.

L.name: LogisticFit
L.description: Fits the data to the form c/(1+a*exp(-b*x).

L.name: LogisticFitModel
L.description: Finds the model that fits the data to the form c/(1+a*exp(-b*x).

L.name: LogisticFitPlot
L.description: Fits and plots the data to the form c/(1+a*exp(-b*x).

L.name: Lucas
L.description:
Returns the nth Lucas number.

If z is given, returns the Lucas polynomial of z.

M.name: MatrixLU
M.description: Returns the matrix decomposition as the product of a lower triangular matrix and an upper triangular matrix.

M.name: MatrixMap
M.description: Creates a new matrix by calling a script or a mapped value on each element.

M.name: MatrixQR
M.description:
Returns the QR factorization or QR decomposition of matrix A.

The first element returned is the orthogonal matrix (usually denoted as Q). The second element returned is the upper triangular matrix (R).

M.name: MatrixSVD
M.description: Returns a list with singular values of a matrix A.

M.name: Mean
M.description: Finds the average of a given list of numbers.

M.name: MedianFit
M.description: Fits the data to the form y=a*x+b using the median-median line technique.

M.name: MedianFitModel
M.description: Finds the model that fits the data to the form y=a*x+b using the median-median line technique.

M.name: MedianFitPlot
M.description: Fits and plots the data to the form y=a*x+b using the median-median line technique.

M.name: Message
M.description: This will stop all computations and display a message.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
n=5
if n>0
Message("Positive")
else if n<0
Message("Negative")
else
Message("Zero")
end
result

M.name: Mod
M.description:
Calculates the following formula.
m-n*floor(m/n)

The sign of mod(m,n) always equals the sign of n.

M.name: MultiPlot
M.description:
Plots multiple types of 2D plots on the same graph. Each parameter must be a plot function or an integer which represents the index of an entry.

MultiPlot supports the following plot functions as parameters.
Plot, ParametricPlot, PolarPlot, ImplicitPlot, ContourPlot, VectorPlot.

examples.title: Examples
rows: MultiPlot(Plot(sin(x), color=red, shade=middle), PolarPlot(2sin(2@theta), color=orange, @theta=[0,2@pi,100]), ParametricPlot(cos(u), sin(u), color=magenta))

M.name: MultiPlot3D
M.description:
Plots multiple types of 3D plots on the same graph. Each parameter must be a plot function or an integer which represents the index of an entry.

MultiPlot3D supports the following plot functions as parameters.
Plot3D, ParametricPlot3D, SphericalPlot3D, CylindricalPlot3D, ContourPlot, VectorPlot3D.

N.name: nCr
N.description:
Returns the number of unordered subsets of r elements out of a set of n elements

nCr(n,r) = n! / ((n-r)! * r!)

N.name: NIntegrate
N.description: Finds the definite integral of the given function by a numerical integration method. The limits of integration are a (lower limit) and b (upper) limit.

N.name: Norm
N.description: Returns the norm of the given vector A.

N.name: NormalCDF
N.description: Computes the normal cumulative density function over the interval from lower to upper with mean mu and standard deviation sigma.

parameters.name: [mu]
parameters.text: This optional parameter is a real number with default value 0.

parameters.name: [sigma]
parameters.text: This optional parameter is a real number with default value 1.

N.name: NormalPDF
N.description: Computes either the normal probability density function at x with mean mu and standard deviation sigma. The default values are mu = 0 and sigma = 1.

N.name: nPr
N.description:
Returns the number of permutations of a subset of r elements from a set of n elements.

nPr(n,r) = n! / (n-r)!

N.name: nPrimes
N.description:
Finds all prime factors and their exponent of a given number.

The result is returned as a nested list. The first number is the prime factor and the second number is the exponent.

N.name: nRoot
N.description: Finds the nth root of a given value. All roots are returned as a list.

parameters.name: [mode]
parameters.text:
mode = 0 returns ONLY real roots (except for complex z)
mode = 1 returns ALL roots, real and complex

P.name: ParametricPlot
P.description:
Plots 2D parametric graphs.

See Plot for documentation on plot parameters.

P.name: ParametricPlot3D
P.description: Plots 3D parametric graphs.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
c1=u/2
c2=v/2
c3=sin(c1)
c4=sin(v)
c5=cos(c1)
c6=sin(2v)
c7=2
c8=c7+c5*c4-c3*c6
ParametricPlot3D(c8*cos(u),c8*sin(u),c3*c4+c5*c6,u=[0,2@pi,40],v=[0,2@pi,40],axis=0)

a=(1+0.4cos(v))cos(u)
b=(1+0.4cos(v))sin(u)
c=0.4sin(v)
ParametricPlot3D([[c,b+1,a],[a,b,c]], colors=[yellow,red], lines=0, axis=0 ,u=[0,2@pi,30], v=[0,2@pi,30])

P.name: Part
P.description:
Returns the nth part of the expression.

This function can be used to iterate recursively through an entire expression.

When n=0 the part of the expression is returned as a string.

P.name: pDiff
P.description:
Finds the partial derivative of the function to the independent variable list.

The dependent variables are a given function of the independent variables. This equation is given in the equation list.

P.name: Pi_Digits
P.description:
Calculates Pi up to the requested number of digits.

The maximum number of digits which can be calculated is 500.

Please note that the larger the number n, the slower the calculation.

P.name: Plot
P.description: Plots 2D function graphs.

examples.title: Examples
rows: Plot(4sin(x), color=blue, shade=middle, shadeColor=[1,0,1,0.5], lines=6, lineDash=[20,5])

P.name: Plot3D
P.description: Plots 3D function graphs.

P.name: Pochhammer
P.description: Finds the value of n*(n+1)*(n+2)*..*(n+k-1)

P.name: PoissonCDF
P.description: Computes the cumulative Poisson distribution at x with mean mu.

P.name: PoissonPDF
P.description: Computes the Poisson distribution at x with mean mu.

P.name: PolarPlot
P.description:
Plots 2D polar plots.

See Plot for documentation on plot parameters.

P.name: PolyDivide
P.description:
Returns both the quotient and remainder from the polynomial division of numerator f(z) and denominator g(z).

Both numerator and denominator should be polynomial functions.

The returned result is a list with the first term the quotient and the second term the remainder.

P.name: PolyFit
P.description: Finds a unique polynomial function of order N-1 through the given N data points.

parameters.name: pList
parameters.text: A list with datapoints given in a [N,2] matrix.  This list should be greater than 1 and less than 11.

parameters.name: var
parameters.text: Optional variable for the returned polynomial. If not given, then var=x.

examples.title: Finds the line between the point [1,3] and [5,7]
Finds the parabolic curve through the points [2,4], [3,1], [5,7]
Finds the cubic curve through the points [0,1], [2,5], [3,4], [5,7]

P.name: PolyGamma
P.description: Returns the PolyGamma function.

parameters.name: n
parameters.text:
n can be any integer >= -1
When n==-1 the LnGamma(z) function is returned.
When n==0 the DiGamma(z) or Psi(z) function is returned.
When n>0 the (n+1) derivative of the Logarithm of the Gamma(z) function is returned.

P.name: PolyGCD
P.description:
Finds the Greatest Common Divisor of two given polynomials.

The maximum number of polynomials that can be given inside PolyGCD is restricted to two.

P.name: PolyLCM
P.description: Finds the least common multiple of two given polynomials.  The maximum number of polynomials that can be given inside PolyLCM is restricted to two.

parameters.name: [mode=1]
parameters.text: The result is an expanded polynomial while in all other cases, the result is returned as the multiplication of 2 polynomials.

P.name: PolyLog
P.description: Returns the Polylogarithm function of z.

parameters.name: n
parameters.text: n can be any integer (positive or negative).  When n=2, you can also use the command DiLog(z)

P.name: PowerExpand
P.description: Expands powers.

P.name: PowerFit
P.description: Fits the data to the form y = a*x<sup>b</sup>.

P.name: PowerFitModel
P.description: Find the model that fits the data to the form y = a*x<sup>b</sup>.

P.name: PowerFitPlot
P.description: Fits and plots the data to the form y = a*x<sup>b</sup>.

P.name: Prime
P.description: Returns a list of prime numbers.

P.name: Primorial
P.description: Returns the product of all primes less than or equal to "n"

P.name: Product
P.description: Calculates the product of f(n) where n goes from start to end.

P.name: Psi
P.description: Calculates the Psi(z) or DiGamma(z).

Q.name: QuadraticFit
Q.description: Fits the data to the form a*x^2+b*x+c.

Q.name: QuadraticFitModel
Q.description: Finds the model that fits the data to the form a*x^2+b*x+c.

Q.name: QuadraticFitPlot
Q.description: Fits and plots the data to the form a*x^2+b*x+c.

Q.name: QuarticFit
Q.description: Fits the data to the form a*x^4+b*x^3+c*x^2+d*x+e.

Q.name: QuarticFitModel
Q.description: Finds the model that fits the data to the form a*x^4+b*x^3+c*x^2+d*x+e.

Q.name: QuarticFitPlot
Q.description: Fits and plots the data to the form a*x^4+b*x^3+c*x^2+d*x+e.

Q.name: Quotient
Q.description:
Returns the quotient from the polynomial division of numerator f(z) and denominator g(z).

Both numerator and denominator should be polynomial functions.

R.name: Random
R.description: Generates a random number between min and max.

R.name: Re
R.description: Returns the real part of a complex number.

R.name: RealPart
R.description: Returns the real part of a complex expression.

R.name: Remainder
R.description:
Returns the remainder from the polynomial division of numerator f(x) and denominator g(x).

Both numerator and denominator should be polynomial functions.

R.name: Replace
R.description: Replaces an expression with another expression.

R.name: Reshape
R.description: Reshapes a matrix to a different size.  The new size of the matrix must have the same number of elements as the original matrix.

R.name: Return
R.description: Returns an expression and stops all other calculations.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
n=1
if n > 0 return "Positive"
if n < 0 return "Negative"
return "Zero"

R.name: Reverse
R.description: Sorts a list in descending order.

R.name: Right
R.description: Returns the right side of an expression.

parameters.name: function
parameters.text: Expression or name of a script

parameters.name: N=10
parameters.text: Number of partitions in the domain [a,b]

parameters.name: function
parameters.text: Expression or name of a script

parameters.name: N=20
parameters.text: Number of partitions in the domain [a,b]

R.name: Round
R.description:
Rounds a given number to the requested number of digits.

The parameter number can be a real or complex value. In case of a complex value, both real and imaginary parts will be rounded.

R.name: RowReduce
R.description:
Performs a Gaussian elimination on the given matrix A.

Note: This function is equivalent to rref on the TI-Calculators.

S.name: SawToothWave
S.description: Creates a predefined 2D sawtooth wave with period = T.  The default value of T is 2π.

S.name: Sequence
S.description: Returns a sequence as a list.

S.name: Series
S.description: Finds the series expansion of a function around zero.  This function is the same as the Maclaurin series.  This function can be used on all common and most special functions.

S.name: Shi
S.description: Finds the Hyperbolic Sine Integral of z.

S.name: Si
S.description: Sine Integral of z.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
for i in 1..3
a @= Si(i)
b @= Ci(i)
end
[a, b]

S.name: Sign
S.description:
Returns the sign of a given value.

If z is a complex number, then sign returns z/abs(z).

S.name: SimplifyFunction
S.description: Reduces trigonometric and exponential functions to functions with simplified argument(s).

S.name: SimplifyPoly
S.description: Simplifies polynomial quotients f(x)/g(x) by factoring the numerator f(x), the denominator g(x) and then calculating the final factored form.

parameters.name: f(x)/g(x)
parameters.text:
This parameter can be any of the following forms.
f(x) , f(x)/g(x) , f(x)^n/g(x) , f(x)/g(x)^n

parameters.name: [variable]
parameters.text: This parameter is optional.  If a variable is not specified MathStudio will search for the correct variable.

S.name: sin
S.description: Computes the sine function of a given input, which can be complex-valued.

S.name: SinFit
S.description: Fits the data to the form a*sin(b*x+c)+d.

S.name: SinFitModel
S.description: Finds the model that fits the data to the form a*sin(b*x+c)+d.

S.name: SinFitPlot
S.description: Fits and plots the data to the form a*sin(b*x+c)+d.

S.name: Size
S.description: Returns the size of the list or matrix.

S.name: Slider
S.description: The Slider function dynamically changes the value of a variable or list of variables using a scrollbar.

S.name: Solve
S.description:
Solves the expression for the given variable.

When no equals sign is given, Solve assumes the expression is equal to zero. For example, Solve(x^2-3) will solve the expression as x^2-3=0.

Quadratic equations can be solved by entering each coefficient as a parameter. For instance, Solve(5x^2+3x+4) may also be entered as Solve(5,3,4).

Solve can also solve a system of equations.
Solve(equation1, equation2, equation3, ...)

parameters.name: [guess]
parameters.text: The initial guess value to solve the equation. If a list of two values is given such as Solve(sin(x)=0,x,[0,6@pi]), Solve will return the solutions within the given range.

S.name: SolveSystem
S.description: Solves a non-linear systems of equations numerically.

S.name: Sort
S.description: Sorts a list in ascending order.

S.name: SphericalPlot3D
S.description: Plots 3D graphs in spherical coordinates.

S.name: Sqrt
S.description: Returns the square root of a given number real or complex.

S.name: SquareWave
S.description: SquareWave is a predefined 2D plot function.  It creates a square wave of period = T.

S.name: StaircaseWave
S.description: Creates a predefined 2D staircase wave with period = T.

S.name: StandardDeviation
S.description: Finds the standard deviation of a list of numbers.

S.name: String
S.description: Creates a string from a list of parameters.

S.name: StudentTCDF
S.description: Computes the Student-t cumulative density function over the interval defined by lower and upper with degrees of freedom df.

S.name: StudentTPDF
S.description: Computes the Student-t probability density function at a value x with degrees of freedom df.

S.name: Sum
S.description: Calculates the sum of f(n) where n goes from start to end.

S.name: SurfaceNormal
S.description:
Calculates the normal vector to the surface given by function at point.

Both the positive and negative normal vectors are returned.

parameters.name: [point]
parameters.text: If point is given, then the normal vector is calculated at the given point. If not, then [x, y, z] is used.

T.name: Together
T.description: Finds a common denominator for each additive term of a polynomial function and returns an equivalent expression with one numerator and one denominator. It performs the opposite operation as Apart.

T.name: Trace
T.description: Trace outputs the value of a variable for debugging.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
numbers = [one, two, three, four, five]
for n in numbers
trace(n)
end

T.name: Transpose
T.description: Calculates the transpose of a matrix A.

T.name: TriangleWave
T.description: TriangleWave is a predefine 2D plotfunction which creates a triangle wave.

parameters.name: [T]
parameters.text: The period and the default value is 2π when not given.

T.name: TrigConvert
T.description: Converts trigonometric functions to exponential functions.

T.name: TrigExpand
T.description: Splits up sums and integer multiples that appear in arguments of trigonometric functions and expands products of trigonometric functions into sums of powers.

examples.title: Sum or difference of two angles

T.name: TrigReduce
T.description: Rewrites products and powers of trigonometric functions in expr in terms of trigonometric functions with combined arguments.

V.name: Variables
V.description: Returns a list variables found in the expression.

V.name: Variance
V.description: Finds the variance of a list of numbers.

W.name: While
W.description: This will loop through and evaluate a block of code until condition evaluates to zero.

examples.title: Examples
rows:
n=0
while n<10
n++
end
n

Z.name: Zeta
Z.description:
If a is not given, finds the Riemann Zeta.

If a is given, finds the Hurwitz Zeta function.

Options.title: Fraction Limit
Options.text: Displays decimals for numbers smaller than this value.

Options.title: Smart Solve
Options.text: Smart Solve reduces and solves input like sqrt(5) and x^2=9.

Options.title: Smart Output
Options.text: Smart Output uses different options depending on the result.

examples:
Plot(sin(x), color=blue)
ParametricPlot(cos(u), sin(u), color=red)
PolarPlot(sin(2@theta), color=green)
ParametricPlot(2cos(u), 2sin(u), color=magenta)

examples:
